author: By Victor Mather
title: U.S. women face Canada in a soccer semifinal on Day 10 of the Games.
description: Gymnastics event finals continue for the women, and the U.S. baseball team plays Japan.
content: TOKYO — The U.S. women’s soccer team lost a game, tied another and needed penalties to beat the Netherlands in the quarterfinals. But the team remains alive, with a semifinal game against Canada on Monday at 5 p.m. Tokyo time, 4 a.m. Eastern. (Follow live coverage.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: ‘X’ Marks the Spot: Officials Map a Route Out of the Pandemic
description: Governments and organizations around the world are using geospatial data and digital mapping tools to guide their vaccination campaigns.
content: At their regular pandemic response meetings over the past year, officials in Suffolk County, N.Y., found themselves returning, again and again, to questions of geography.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: In addition to Covid, more children are getting a respiratory virus more commonly seen in winter.
description: An outbreak of respiratory syncytial virus, combined with growing Covid-19 pediatric cases, is straining hospital resources in some U.S. cities.
content: U.S. health officials have expressed concern over a simultaneous rise in Delta infections and cases of respiratory syncytial virus, a highly contagious seasonal flulike illness that is more likely to affect children and older adults.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Who Are the Unvaccinated in America?
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 1, 2021.
content: “We live in an era of unprecedented scientific breakthroughs and expertise. But we’re also stymied by the forces of misinformation that undermine the true knowledge that is out there.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 1, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 1, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about the vogue legend Archie Burnett misspelled the name of a performer. She is Princess Lockerooo, not Princess Lockeroo. The article also referred imprecisely to Burnett. While he has been referred to as the father of the House of Ninja, he now prefers to be known as the grandfather of the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Montgomery
title: Gov. Greg Abbott bars mandates for vaccinations and masks in Texas.
description: The state’s daily average of cases has risen more than 200 percent over the past 14 days and hospitalizations are surging, but an executive order ensures that masking and vaccinations remain voluntary.
content: Many states, cities, businesses and schools have been scrambling to institute new mandates since Tuesday, when the federal health authorities recommended that even fully vaccinated people should wear masks again in public indoor spaces in Delta-variant hot spots and urged universal masking in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman, Talya Minsberg and David W. Chen
title: Shot-Putter’s Gesture Renews Controversy Over Podium Protests
description: Raven Saunders of the United States crossed her arms over her head. A second athlete, the American fencer Race Imboden, accepted a medal with a symbol drawn on his hand.
content: TOKYO — In the morning, Raven Saunders of the United States captured the silver medal in the shot-put.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Sunday night includes gymnastics, volleyball and basketball.
description: Gymnastics and track & field will hold finals, and the U.S. women’s soccer team faces Canada.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage on Sunday evening and overnight. Early on Monday morning, Megan Rapinoe and the U.S. women’s soccer team head into the semifinals. Follow The New York Times for live updates when the game starts at 4 a.m. on USA Network. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isadora Kosofsky and Shawn Hubler
title: A New Surge at a Santa Monica I.C.U.
description: They thought the worst of the pandemic was behind them. Then a new wave of cases arrived at the I.C.U. at Providence Saint John’s Health Center.
content: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Two months ago at Providence Saint John’s Health Center, Dr. Morris Grabie stood at a makeshift plastic wall in the intensive care unit and prayed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Banged on the Trunk of His Cab and Reprimanded Him’
description: A nice walk interrupted, a front seat solo and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Christopher Flavelle
title: A Brain Drain Among Government Scientists Bogs Down Biden’s Climate Ambitions
description: Hundreds of scientists and policy experts left the government during the Trump administration. The jobs remain unfilled nearly six months into President Biden’s term, slowing his climate agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — Juliette Hart quit her job last summer as an oceanographer for the United States Geological Survey, where she used climate models to help coastal communities plan for rising seas. She was demoralized after four years of the Trump administration, she said, in which political appointees pressured her to delete or downplay mentions of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisia’s President Holds Forth on Freedoms After Seizing Power
description: “‘Why do you think that, at 67, I would start a career as a dictator?’” President Kais Saied said in a meeting with The New York Times, quoting Charles de Gaulle. He vowed to preserve hard-fought rights.
content: TUNIS — The man who critics were warning could become Tunisia’s next dictator locked eyes with me and intoned, “Welcome to Tunisia, where freedom of speech is protected with no interference in personal freedoms at all.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: China continues its diving dominance, winning gold and silver in the women’s 3-meter springboard.
description: Shi Tingmao won gold and Wang Han took silver, underlining China’s mastery of this precision sport, in which perfection must be achieved in a couple seconds. Krysta Palmer of the U.S. took bronze.
content: They make it look easy: crisp gymnastics through the air, knifing impact with the water and barely a splash upon entry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: A World War II Spy Didn’t Live to Tell Her Tale. Her Great-Great-Niece Will.
description: In her book, “All the Frequent Troubles of Our Days,” Rebecca Donner examines the life of Mildred Harnack, part of the anti-Nazi resistance in Germany.
content: Every year when Rebecca Donner visited her great-grandmother’s home in Chevy Chase, Md., she and her brother would stand against the kitchen wall to have their heights marked in pencil. When she turned 9, she noticed a letter M near one of the faintest lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos
title: ‘It Looked Like an Atomic Bomb’: Surveying the Bootleg Fire’s Devastation
description: For one couple, Oregon’s Bootleg Fire all but erased their home, leaving little except memories and a tan chimney spire.
content: BEATTY, Ore. — Marc Valens washed his hands in the rubble of what was once his home, in the bowl where he used to make salad. There was something almost normal about it all: the clink and clank of lids and pots as he stood at the still-intact sink and stove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: A PGA Star Wins Gold in Golf, an Event Unmoored From the Games
description: Xander Schauffele defeated a field of pros on the manicured grounds of a former men-only club, in a sport still struggling to get into the Olympic spirit.
content: KAWAGOE, Japan — There were few clues that the Olympic men’s golf tournament had anything in common with the 32 other sports at the Tokyo Summer Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: A Fight Over Zoning Tests Charlottesville’s Progress on Race
description: Four years after a white supremacist march, the Virginia city is reconsidering its housing and zoning rules.
content: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — In early July, crews showed up downtown for some long-delayed evictions. After years of protest, litigation and even violence, the statues of two Confederate generals, Lee and Jackson, were finally carted out of city parks, expelled by the city’s drive to right its past wrongs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Nina Derwael seizes gold in the uneven bars as Sunisa Lee falters.
description: Lee completed a much less difficult routine because she failed to connect several of her skills.
content: Nina Derwael of Belgium took advantage of her rivals’ mistakes and nerves during the uneven bars final on Sunday to win the gold medal in her specialty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Sunken ‘Jungle Cruise’ Sales Reflect Hollywood’s Delta Variant Troubles
description: The mega-budget comedic adventure took in $34 million in North America and $30 million on Disney+ worldwide.
content: LOS ANGELES — As Disney’s pun-filled “Jungle Cruise” demonstrated over the weekend, moviegoing remains disrupted, with the Delta variant, immediate streaming availability and squishy reviews combining to depress ticket sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Bobby Finke’s Big Finish Surprises Himself, and His Rivals
description: An American grinds out a gold in the 1,500-meter freestyle by saving a little extra for the finish.
content: TOKYO — Even Bobby Finke didn’t know he could swim this fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Payments App Square to Acquire Australian Company Afterpay
description: The deal, for $29 billion, would introduce Afterpay’s “buy now, pay later” service to U.S. consumers and the small businesses that process their credit card transactions on Square.
content: Two financial technology giants that are taking on the traditional banking industry are joining forces to build their alternative to credit cards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Italians Stun Even Themselves in 100 Meters and High Jump
description: Lamont Marcell Jacobs won the men’s 100 meters and Gianmarco Tamberi shared gold in the high jump a day after discussing how improbable it would be if they won.
content: TOKYO — The man in Lane 3 was a mystery to nearly everyone, including the world-class sprinters who had lined up next to him for one of the biggest races on one of the biggest stages in sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: With Undersea Robots, an Air Force Navigator Lost Since 1967 Is Found
description: A recovery mission off Vietnam’s coast showed how advances in technology have given new reach to the Pentagon’s search for American war dead.
content: On a July morning in 1967, two American B-52 bombers collided over the South China Sea as they approached a target in what was then South Vietnam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: To Fight Vaccine Lies, Authorities Recruit an ‘Influencer Army’
description: The White House has teamed up with TikTok stars, while some states are paying “local micro influencers” for pro-vaccine campaigns.
content: LOS ANGELES — Ellie Zeiler, 17, a TikTok creator with over 10 million followers, received an email in June from Village Marketing, an influencer marketing agency. It said it was reaching out on behalf of another party: the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Riots Shatter Veneer of Coexistence in Israel’s Mixed Towns
description: Israel’s Jewish and Palestinian communities looked past each other until violence and bloodshed forced a reckoning.
content: ACRE, Israel — Uri Jeremias, a celebrated Israeli chef, saw himself as a benefactor. By bringing jobs, tourists and investment to the mainly Arab heart of the coastal town of Acre, he believed he was seen as nurturing coexistence between Jews and Arabs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Alexander Zverev wins gold in the men’s singles tennis tournament.
description: Zverev had beaten Novak Djokovic, the top-ranked men’s player, in the semifinal.
content: Alexander Zverev just might have figured something out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Does Back to School Mean a Jacket and Slacks?
description: A reader wonders how to dress at medical school.
content: First, please thank your son for his service over the last year. I am sure it made a difference to many people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Wait, How Does Everyone Have Bushy Eyebrows?
description: It might be natural, or it might be eyebrow lamination.
content: Perhaps you’ve noticed all the bushy eyebrows on TikTok, brushed up to resemble fuzzy caterpillars, and wondered: How?
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Is There a Right Way to Act Blind?’
description: Activists slammed the TV show “In the Dark” for casting a sighted actress in a blind lead role. But what if blindness is a performance of its own?
content: Andrew Leland is caught somewhere between sight and blindness. He is blind but not in the way people expect. He can make eye contact, read street signs and watch TV. But that causes others to question (sometimes audibly) whether he is faking it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Tokyo Convenience Store Chicken Gizzards Saved My Life
description: Cut off from most restaurants because of coronavirus restrictions, thousands of international visitors at the Olympics make do — and delight — in convenience store offerings.
content: TOKYO — On languid bus rides from one Olympic venue to another, a panorama of gustatory pleasures rolls by: noodle joints, skewer shops, sushi counters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Once in a Blue Moon
description: Kyra Wilson serves up some meteorology.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Kyra Wilson, who is making her solo New York Times Crossword debut after three collaborations with Sophia Maymudes in rapid succession over the past four months! Although I try to keep the math to a minimum around here (this isn’t Numberplay, after all), that works out to a puzzle per month for Ms. Wilson — quite a few more than the typical rate of “once in a blue moon” that most constructors see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Dana Rubinstein
title: Mass Shooting in Queens Leaves 10 Wounded
description: As seven bystanders were injured in a shooting, Eric Adams called on New York City authorities to intensify efforts against gangs and guns.
content: It seemed like an ordinary Saturday night on a stretch of 37th Avenue in Queens: Men gathered in front of a barbershop, a restaurant hosted a birthday party and a shopkeeper waited for customers inside a meat market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: The U.S. is wasting vaccine doses, even as cases rise and other countries suffer shortages.
description: A survey of data from 10 states shows that more than one million doses have been lost because of spoilage, missed appointments and other problems.
content: A survey of data from 10 states shows that more than one million doses have gone to waste since the nation began administering Covid-19 vaccines in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Zoom Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Over ‘Zoombombing’
description: The videoconferencing company said it would pay $85 million to settle the suit, which claimed that it violated users’ privacy, in part by allowing hackers to interrupt online meetings.
content: Zoom Video Communications, the videoconferencing company whose internet app became a mainstay of American life during the coronavirus pandemic, has agreed to pay $85 million and improve its security practices to settle a lawsuit claiming it violated the privacy of its users.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Olympic Sprinter From Belarus Seeks Refuge in Japan, Fearing Jail at Home
description: Belarus tried to force the sprinter, Kristina Timanovskaya, to return home after she criticized her coaches for registering her for the wrong event.
content: A Belarusian sprinter said Sunday that she was under the protection of the Japanese police after her country’s Olympic Committee tried, but failed, to forcibly send her home after she criticized her coaches for registering her for the wrong event.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cut off from restaurants, Tokyo’s visitors find culinary delights at 24-hour convenience stores.
description: TOKYO — Noodle joints, skewer shops, sushi counters. Those of us who are here covering the Games stare at it all through tinted glass on languid bus rides from one Olympic venue to another.
content: TOKYO — Noodle joints, skewer shops, sushi counters. Those of us who are here covering the Games stare at it all through tinted glass on languid bus rides from one Olympic venue to another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Afghans are fleeing the Taliban advance.
content: A mass exodus is unfolding across Afghanistan as the Taliban press on with a military campaign and the U.S. withdraws. At least 30,000 Afghans are leaving each week and many more have been displaced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: In swimming’s finale, the U.S. men keep their unbeaten streak alive, and Emma McKeon gets her 7th medal.
description: McKeon picked up two more golds, giving her a record-tying seven medals in Tokyo, and Caeleb Dressel swam away with his fourth and fifth golds.
content: TOKYO — The medals, dozens of them, arrived in singles and in bunches, in short races and long ones, in medleys and relays. But every day, it seemed, the United States and Australia tossed a few more on the pile. Sunday was no different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Ruby
title: BMX freestyle, a new event, enthralls as Britain and Australia take first golds.
description: The ramps have a variety of transitions, thrusting riders skyward before they land back in the ramp and onto the next trick.
content: TOKYO — New for the Tokyo Games, BMX freestyle is an expert display of bike handling and airborne trickery as riders soar through a ramped course exclusive to their 20-inch wheeled bicycles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Priceless? Even Olympic Medals Can Be Had for the Right Price
description: Some former Olympians have resorted to selling their medals because of financial hardships or to raise money for charity.
content: A silver medal in shooting from the 1900 Olympics in Paris recently sold for a mere $1,283.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan’s gold medal win over China in badminton raises tension.
description: The Taiwanese badminton duo Lee Yang and Wang Chi-lin, who beat a Chinese team to take gold, had emphasized their Taiwanese identity on social media.
content: At the medal ceremony for the badminton men’s doubles on Saturday, the winning players watched a flag being raised, but it was not their own. They sang as a song reverberated in the mostly empty venue, but it was not their anthem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Yulimar Rojas, with a world-record triple jump, becomes the first female Olympic gold medalist from Venezuela.
description: Rojas, a triple jumper, thought she could make a bid for the world record and did.
content: Yulimar Rojas of Venezuela had high hopes coming into these Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Nobody Wants to Live in a Nursing Home. Something’s Got to Give.
description: America needs more infrastructure for the elderly.
content: Few people dream of living out their golden years in a nursing home. The very idea sparks existential dread in many Americans, conjuring images of grim, institutional dumping grounds where society’s frailest and most vulnerable members aren’t so much cared for as warehoused. Scattered horror stories of neglect and abuse supercharge more prosaic fears about losing one’s autonomy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy wins the 100-meter dash.
description: Jacobs finished in 9.80 seconds, with Fred Kerley of the United States second and Andre De Grasse of Canada third.
content: TOKYO — There is a new fastest man in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The G.O.P. Menace to Society
description: It is delusional to not tell the unvarnished truth because you believe your tone of conciliation will lead to rehabilitation.
content: It feels like every week now we learn of a new way that Donald Trump posed a threat to American democracy when he was president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 2 Dead in Random Shooting at ‘Purge’ Movie, Officials Say
description: Anthony Barajas, who was popular on TikTok, and Rylee Goodrich were each shot in the head at a theater in Corona, Calif., in what the district attorney said was an unprovoked attack.
content: A second person died on Saturday after being shot during a screening of “The Forever Purge,” a movie about anarchy and murder, at a California theater in what the authorities called a “random and unprovoked attack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: N.I.H. director says asking for proof of vaccination is a step ‘in the right direction.’
description: Businesses and government agencies are pushing employees to get vaccinated amid a surge in new coronavirus infections across the country.
content: As cases and hospitalizations rise across the country, Dr. Francis Collins, director of the National Institutes of Health, said on Sunday that businesses asking employees for proof of vaccination or regular testing were taking steps “in the right direction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Robinhood Fizzled as Silicon Valley Sizzled
description: The stock-trading app Robinhood had a weak stock market opening, while Silicon Valley companies continued to set new earnings records.
content: Robinhood’s highly anticipated public offering fizzled on Thursday. Shares in the stock-trading start-up opened at $38, but ended the day down 8.4 percent. The decline reflected investors’ skepticism of Robinhood’s grand mission of upending Wall Street. As part of that mission to democratize investing, Robinhood offered as many as a third of its initial shares to its customers through its app. That could have reduced a first-day trading “pop,” which is typically driven by retail investors who were shut out of an initial public offering. Robinhood ended Thursday with a value of around $29 billion — still not bad for an eight-year-old company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Top Myanmar General Says Military Rule Will Continue Into 2023
description: Six months after seizing power, the junta’s leader on Sunday extended a state of emergency for two more years. Protesters said they would persevere.
content: Six months to the day after Myanmar’s military staged a coup and imposed a reign of terror over the country, the junta’s leader, Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, said on Sunday that a national state of emergency would be extended for another two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Who is Lamont Marcell Jacobs, Italy’s first fastest man?
description: Lamont Marcell Jacobs, a 26-year-old sprinter who took gold in the 100-meter dash, was born in El Paso to an Italian mother and African American father.
content: Before Sunday, an Italian man had never won an Olympic medal in the 100-meter dash in the Games’ 125-year history. Now, Lamont Marcell Jacobs is the first from Italy to hold the title of world’s fastest man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Xander Schauffele wins the gold medal in golf.
description: It was the first American gold medal in golf since 1904, a gap explained by the sport being dropped after those Games and returning only in 2016.
content: Xander Schauffele of the United States won the gold medal in men’s golf at the Tokyo Olympics on Sunday, edging a crowded group of pursuers to win by a single stroke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristin Kimball
title: Think Sustainability Is Simple? This Sheep Farmer Would Like a Word.
description: Can farmers make money without wrecking the land? That’s the complex question James Rebanks tries to answer in his new book, “Pastoral Song.”
content: PASTORAL SONGA Farmer’s JourneyBy James Rebanks
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Valenti
title: Unvaxxed, Unmasked and Putting Our Kids at Risk
description: Yes, this is a rant against irrationality and vaccines.
content: For days now, vaccinated Americans have been trying to come to terms with the new advice from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention about the rapidly spreading Delta variant and a spike of Covid cases in states with high populations of unvaccinated people. Officials encouraged everyone in high-risk areas to start wearing masks in public indoor spaces again and recommended that all teachers and students wear masks in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia Scoffs at Olympic Ban: ‘Let Them Listen to Classical Music’
description: Sports fans and officials in the country have no trouble seeing through the thin fiction of a doping-related ban on their national symbols at the Tokyo Olympics.
content: MOSCOW — Russia’s Olympic team is competing abroad in unmarked uniforms without the country’s flag — not unlike the Russian Army on its unacknowledged military incursions, as one joke making the rounds in Moscow notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Reynold Ruffins, Push Pin Studios Graphic Artist, Dies at 90
description: With Milton Glaser, Ed Sorel and Seymour Chwast, he was part of a movement that upended the ’50s era advertising style with witty, faux-nostalgic imagery.
content: Reynold Ruffins, an illustrator, graphic designer and artist who was an early member of Push Pin Studios, the impish and buzzy design firm founded by his Cooper Union classmates Milton Glaser, Ed Sorel and Seymour Chwast, died on July 11 at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: A Fire in Minnesota. An Arrest in Mexico. Cameras Everywhere.
description: One night in the Twin Cities, shortly after the killing of George Floyd, someone set a fire in a Goodwill. That led to an international search for the culprits — and it exposed a growing system of global surveillance.
content: Mena Yousif wore dark clothing to the protest, with white sneakers and a blue hijab that she could pull over her face, perfect gear during a pandemic. Jose Felan, stocky and tall, wore a baseball cap and a gray T-shirt that showed off a distinctive tattoo on his forearm: “Mena,” with a crown above the “a.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: On a Refurbished Knee, Brazil’s Andrade Vaults to a Gold Medal
description: Sunisa Lee of the United States, who won the Olympic all-around competition last week and was favored to win on the uneven bars, won bronze in that event instead.
content: TOKYO — On a night of unexpected joy mixed with unexpected disappointment, Rebeca Andrade, a gymnast from Brazil, held her gold medal in the vault on Sunday at the Tokyo Olympics and wondered if it was real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Why Trust Is in Short Supply on Capitol Hill
description: Suspicion and skepticism among lawmakers complicates deal-making.
content: WASHINGTON — Congress is running a serious trust deficit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randal C. Archibold
title: With seven medals at one Olympics, Emma McKeon ties a record.
description: McKeon’s haul ties her for the record by any female Olympian, set in 1952 by gymnast Maria Gorokhovskaya of the Soviet Union.
content: TOKYO — The most decorated Olympic swimmer in Tokyo is … Caeleb Dressel? Katie Ledecky?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meridith Kohut and Isayen Herrera
title: Even the Pope Has Prayed to Venezuela’s Beloved ‘Doctor of the Poor’
description: In a deeply polarized country, suffering an extreme health crisis, one of the few uniting beliefs is the admiration across the political spectrum for a doctor recently beatified by the Vatican.
content: ISNOTÚ, Venezuela — The faithful began arriving before dawn, silhouettes emerging from a thick fog, serenaded by birdsong and clamoring church bells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Rebeca Andrade wins the vault, Brazil’s first gold in women’s gymnastics.
description: MyKayla Skinner of the United States finished second for the silver medal. Yeo Seo-jeong won bronze for South Korea.
content: With two high-flying vaults that made complicated, gravity-defying moves look simple, Rebeca Andrade won the vault final on Sunday at the Tokyo Games, bringing Brazil its first gold medal ever in women’s gymnastics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In Carl Hancock Rux’s ‘Vs.,’ the Jury Is Out
description: Where justice is virtual, crimes have no names and audience members step up to the dock to examine anonymous witnesses.
content: Since the pandemic began, American courts have moved millions of hearings online, a development known as “virtual justice.” Carl Hancock Rux’s elliptical “Vs.” adapts virtual justice as virtual theater. In this court, the crime remains unnamed and the identity of the accused a mystery. The interrogator? That would be you. Or at least, a silhouette of you, with some mild technological wizardry superimposing someone else’s deep voice atop your blacked-out outline. Anyway, choose your Zoom background with care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: The Olympics That Feel Like Only Competitions
description: A reporter in Tokyo finds himself missing the unscripted moments beyond winning and losing.
content: TOKYO — These are not like any other Olympics, and it is as obvious as the empty seats in the background. Television audiences can tell that something is amiss simply by what is missing: people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Can Paramount+ Succeed? One Producer Hopes to Make It So.
description: “He’s our future,” one CBS Studios executive said of Alex Kurtzman, who has a lucrative contract to expand the “Star Trek” universe — and with it the streaming service’s audience.
content: Like so many other writer-directors, Alex Kurtzman grew up worshiping film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Lollapalooza Drops DaBaby From Lineup After His Homophobic Remarks
description: The rapper was criticized for asking fans at a performance last week to raise their phones in the air if they didn’t have H.I.V. or AIDS.
content: DaBaby’s scheduled performance at the Lollapalooza music festival in Chicago was canceled on Sunday after the rapper made homophobic comments that other music artists condemned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: N.Y.P.D. Searches for Suspects in Queens Shooting That Wounded 10
description: Police said two gunmen opened fire on a crowd near a busy intersection in North Corona, Queens, on Saturday night, injuring seven bystanders and three alleged members of the Trinitarios gang. The shooters fled with help from two accomplices on scooters.

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Tiffany Hsu
title: How Local Media Spreads Misinformation From Vaccine Skeptics
description: Facebook and other social media have been under scrutiny for vaccine misinformation, but local outlets have also sometimes been active.
content: The Freedom’s Phoenix, a local news site in Phoenix, and The Atlanta Business Journal, a news site in Atlanta, both published the same article about coronavirus vaccines in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: If you’re willing to splurge, a lobster roll is a luxurious taste of summer at its simplest.
content: Good morning. I was in Maine earlier this week, talking food journalism with Ruth Reichl at the Summer Institute of the College of the Atlantic on Mount Desert Island, and if talking with Ruth was a dream — in person! Not on a screen! — it was also exhilarating to be out of my bedroom office, taking in the landscape of beautiful places far from home. Plus, the food was sublime: corn salad and lamb chops one night from the Peggy Rockefeller Farms in Bar Harbor; a stuffed lobster roll from Beal’s in Southwest Harbor the following day; an ace banh mi from Saigon Sandwich House in Lowell, Mass., while on the road.
source.name: The New York Times
